title: Troye Sivan speaks candidly about coming out as gay and discovering his identity
text:
He previously said he was uncomfortable with being called a 'gay icon'.

And Troye Sivan has revealed he is still figuring out his identity during an interview with the latest issue Harper's BAZAAR Australia Man.

The singer-songwriter, 24, told the magazine: 'Growing up in a society where I didn't want to be gay for the first 15 years of my life, I was terrified of it.

'I didn't want to be gay for the first 15 years of my life': Australian singer Troye Sivan, 24, revealed his is still figuring who he his after coming out as gay in his teens

Speaking about that fear, he added: 'That's still in there and I'm personally trying to work it out. I'm enjoying this process of pushing myself, figuring out - am I into this? Am I not? There are no rules.'

The Bloom hitmaker revealed he was gay to his fans at age 18 on his YouTube channel in 2013, three years after telling his family who were supportive.

He explained to the publication that coming out to his family has been a different experience to coming out as a person.

'Although I came out as gay to my family, there was still a lot to I hid, the way I wanted to move, dress speak,' the singer said.

Younger years: The singer-songwriter, 24, told Harper's BAZAAR Australia Man: 'Growing up in a society where I didn't want to be gay for the first 15 years of my life, I was terrified of it' (Pictured: Troye in 2014)

Back in 2018, Troye told Another Man magazine that he 'politely declined' being called a 'a gay icon'.

'With people like Hayley Kiyoko and Brockhampton, we're starting to get, finally, a diverse group of different LGBTQ perspectives,' he explained.

'That’s why I politely don’t want to take on that "gay icon" thing. I'm one voice of so many that are missing, and so I’m just trying to tell my story.'

'There was still a lot to I hid': He explained hat although he came out to his family was a different experience to coming out as a person, he said: 'there was still a lot to I hid, the way I wanted to move, dress speak'

Troye, who has been dating model Jacob Bixenman for the past three years, features on the cover of the fashion publication comes after he wrapped his tour of Australia and New Zealand.

The Perth-raised singer said in a previous interview with Sunrise's Edwina Bartholomew: 'I want to take this moment to publicly apologise at how long it's taken me to do this.'

'For me, playing in Australia is like coming home. I really put a lot of pressure on myself to get out there and do a good job,' he added.
description: He has previously said he was uncomfortable with being called a 'gay icon'.
authors: Alisha Buaya For Daily Mail Australia
